Award.AwardTitle: Corporate Downsizing and Restructuring in the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-0961129
PI: Matissa Hollister
Institution: Dartmouth College

The proposed project will make innovative use of a unique dataset, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission EEO-1 reports from 1971 to the present, to examine the economic and social factors behind the rise and spread of downsizing and restructuring as well as the social consequences of these practices. The project will test six competing theories behind the spread of downsizing and restructuring. The project will also examine whether downsizing and restructuring has had a disproportionate impact by race and/or gender and whether these practices contributed to the stagnation of improvements in employment outcomes by race in the 1980s. The analysis will provide insights into organizational behavior and on how new practices emerge and diffuse, as well as the impact of these organizational behaviors on social stratification outcomes.

Broader Impacts
The results will have several implications for public policy. The study may identify new strategies for addressing the negative impacts of downsizing and restructuring. The analysis by race and gender may further point to the need for new employment policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study used data from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) to examine changes in firm structures over time and how these changes have affected employment diversity. The EEOC reports provide data on private U.S. companies with more than 100 employees since 1971. The reports include information on the number of employees at different occupation levels separated by race and gender. While previous researchers have used the EEOC data to examine patterns of employment diversity over time, this study went further by linking the data from year to year to provide longitudinal information about changes occuring within individual firms.

Over a decade ago Gordon (1996) pointed out that despite the rhetoric of corporate downsizing and its stated goal of streamlining companies by removing unnecessary layers of management, the proportion of American workers in management positions has actually grown over time. He argued that companies had become “fat and mean,” using the cover of downsizing to actually increase managerial intensity and compensation at the expense of production workers. Using the EEOC data, though, we found that managerial employment did in fact decline in the 1980s and 1990s, but only in large firms. Smaller firms, in contrast, saw steady increases in managerial intensity to the point that small firms now employ managers at a greater rate than large firms (see figure 1). The analysis further shows that these trends are not due to industry shifts nor the expansion or contraction of firms, but rather reflect broader transformations in employment practices within companies. These findings point to important changes in the structures of firms and their employment arrangements.

The results then demonstrate that this shift in employment practices has important implications for employment diversity. Previous research has found that workplace equality by gender and race improved substantially in the 1970s but that progress towards desegregation by race stalled in the 1980s. We used the EEOC dataset to examine how the divergence in managerial use by firm size has played a role in these trends. The results for women show strong increases in the share of managerial positions held by women within firms of all sizes (see figure 2). Counter to most predictions, female managers seem to be particularly shielded from employment reductions while at the same time they also benefit when firms expand. In contrast, the EEOC data indicate that black men only saw improvements in access to managerial positions at large firms, while the share of managerial positions in the smallest firms held by black men has hardly changed since the 1970s. These findings point to two important issues. First, the results suggest that diversity achievements by race vary systematically by firm size, a phenomena that calls for further investigation. Second, the findings discussed above that documented the reductions in managerial use at large firms points to particular challenges for progress in achieving managerial diversity by race. Since black men only gained access to managerial positions in large firms, the fact that large firms are cutting managerial positions is particularly problematic for this group. Black men were disproportionately affected by these managerial reductions at large firms, and this contributed to the stalling of their progress in the 1980s. These findings provide new insights and avenues for understanding recent trends in employment equality.
